We provide a purely categorical definition of quantum theory. The definition is based on a small number of axioms that are purely categorical and do not presuppose any analytical structure. The axioms are designed to be consistent with the best available mathematical models of quantum theory. The definition is intended to be useful for the reconstruction of quantum theory from first principles.

The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic obligate parasites that cause diseases in a variety of hosts, including humans. Although the evolutionary origin of myxozoans has been elusive, a close relationship with cnidarians, a group that includes corals, sea anemones, jellyfish, and hydroids, is supported by some phylogenetic studies and the observation that the distinctive myxozoan structure, the polar capsule, is remarkably similar to the stinging structures (nematocysts) in cnidarians. Here, we compare the genomes of two distantly related myxozoan species to the genome of the less reduced cnidarian parasite, Polypodium hydriforme. Our results suggest that the degeneration of the myxozoan body plan from a free-living cnidarian to a microscopic parasitic cnidarian was accompanied by extreme reduction in genome size and gene content. This study provides insights into the extreme evolutionary transition from a free-living cnidarian to a microscopic endoparasite. (Less)

COVID-19 is a serious global health problem that has caused more than 200,000 deaths in the United States as of October 2020. The disease is caused by the severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2), which is able to evade the host innate immune response by blocking nuclear import of transcription factors that are essential for the induction of IFN-stimulated genes. Our study shows that SARS-CoV-2 uses a viral protein, Orf6, to block nuclear import of transcription factors. Our results reveal a mechanism of viral antagonism in which a virus hijacks the Nup98-Rae1 complex to overcome the antiviral action of IFN. This study provides a better understanding of the mechanisms used by SARS-CoV-2 to evade the host innate immune response and may lead to the development of new antiviral strategies. (Show more)

Voltage-gated proton channels are involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of proton channels, but the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits proton channels is not completely understood. In this study, we use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of proton channels. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the proton channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric proton channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the proton channel. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits proton channels will further our understanding of proton channel function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for proton channels. We show that the variability of maize yields will increase substantially in the future, even if the mean yield increases. This increase in variability will increase the probability of simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year in the world’s major maize-exporting countries, and it will increase the probability of large price spikes. These results underscore the urgency of investments in breeding for heat tolerance.

The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is a key determinant of biodiversity in the world’s grasslands. However, the extent to which species differ in their diets is largely unknown because of the difficulty of identifying species-level differences in diet. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven species of large herbivore in a semiarid African savanna. We found that diet composition differed between all species, even between pairs of species matched in body size and proportional grass consumption. Such taxonomically fine-grained diet partitioning suggests that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in large herbivore assemblages, and that the diversity of large herbivores may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized.

We conducted a survey of more than 5,800 small businesses in the United States to understand the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on their operations. We find that many small businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. Many businesses are financially fragile, with only about 2 wk of cash on hand at the time of the survey. Moreover, many small businesses plan to apply for loans under the CARES Act, but anticipate problems with accessing the program.

Plastic debris is one of the most visible consequences of human activities in the ocean. However, the magnitude of the problem is still unknown. We show that the global load of floating plastic debris is on the order of tens of thousands of tons, far less than expected. This is due to the size-selective sinks of plastic debris on the open ocean surface. This sink may involve a combination of fast nano-fragmentation of the microplastic into particles of microns or smaller, their transference to the ocean interior by food webs and ballasting processes, and processes yet to be discovered.

The age of the solar system is one of the most important and fundamental facts in astronomy. It is based on the assumption that the solar system is in equilibrium and that the solar system age is the same as the age of the universe. However, the age of the solar system is still a matter of debate.

We provide a comprehensive picture of the evolution of the global fishing fleet over the last 70 y. We show that the global fleet has doubled in size, and the motorized fleet has increased by a factor of 10. We show that the effective CPUE of most countries has decreased by a fifth since 1950, and that there are signs of stabilization and more effective management in recent years. We conclude that the global fleet will continue to grow, but that the effective CPUE will continue to decrease, unless effective management is implemented.

The ability to increase the amount of energy available to the mother is a key component of the evolution of all forms of care. Here, we show that the evolution of care, both allo- and within-litter, is associated with an increase in reproductive output. We also show that the increase in reproductive output is associated with an increase in the amount of energy available to the mother. This suggests that the limiting factor on reproductive output in placental mammals is metabolic power rather than resource availability.

We report here the results of a proof of concept study in a mouse model of multiple system atrophy (MSAsyn) that shows that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765 is able to reduce the load of α-syn aggregates in the striatum of MSAsyn mice. This reduction was associated with a reduction of the number of α-syn-positive neurons in the substantia nigra. These results suggest that VX-765 could be a promising candidate for the treatment of MSAsyn.

The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous data challenges, and the need for timely, accurate, and accessible data is likely to persist for some time. We describe the COVIDcast API, which provides open access to a wide range of data on COVID-19 activity, including many auxiliary signals that are not typically available in public health surveillance. These data are available at a fine geographic resolution and are updated daily. We provide examples of how these data can be used to track the pandemic, augment traditional public health reporting, and empower research and decision-making. We hope that the COVIDcast API will be a useful resource for the public health community and beyond.

The selectivity filter is the narrowest part of the pore of K+ channels, and it is the site of ion conduction. Inactivation is a fundamental process in all ion channels, and it is also a key mechanism in the inactivation of K+ channels. Inactivation is a state-dependent process, and it is characterized by the collapse of the selectivity filter. We have identified a key residue for the communication between the activation gate and the selectivity filter in K+ channels. We have also demonstrated that the selectivity filter can be structurally collapsed by the structural collapse of the activation gate. This work provides a structural basis for the allosteric communication between the activation gate and the selectivity filter. It also provides a structural basis for the structural collapse of the selectivity filter. This work is expected to provide a structural basis for the design of new drugs for K+ channel-related diseases. It also provides a structural basis for the design of new drugs for K+ channel-related diseases.

The gut microbiome is a complex ecosystem that is thought to play a role in the health of the host. However, the mechanisms by which the microbiome influences the host are not well understood. In this study, we investigate the potential of anaerobic gut fungi to synthesize natural products that could regulate membership within the gut microbiome. We find that anaerobic gut fungi synthesize a variety of natural products, which could be used to regulate the composition of the gut microbiome. These results support the idea that anaerobic gut fungi are important contributors to the health of the host.

Social dominance is a fundamental aspect of social groups, but whether personality traits may predispose individuals to a particular rank remains unclear. Here we show that trait anxiety directly influences social dominance in male outbred rats and identify an important mediating role for mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. Our findings highlight a key role for brain energy metabolism in social behavior and point to mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens as a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders.

This work is devoted to the development of a new paradigm for the design of mechanical devices. The proposed approach is based on the synthesis of composite structures that are composed of multiple material phases, which are optimally designed to produce specific responses under large deformations. The synthesized structures are then manufactured via multimaterial fabrication and assembled into architectures that exhibit highly complex and navigable responses. The proposed approach can be utilized to design mechanical devices with specific target behaviors for a wide range of applications.

The hemoglobin system is a major target for the study of human aging and the impact of chronic disease. Here we show that the IGF2BP1 protein, a component of the let-7 miRNA pathway, is expressed in the human erythroid system and that it can affect the expression of hemoglobin in human erythroblasts. This study provides a mechanism for chronoregulation of hemoglobin expression in humans.

Cancer is the leading cause of death worldwide, and the development of new therapies is urgently needed. In this study, we identified a mechanism of resistance to ferroptosis, a form of regulated necrosis driven by iron-dependent peroxidation of phospholipids, which is highly relevant to cancer. We found that mutation of the PI3K or loss of phosphatase and tensin homolog deleted on chromosome 10 (PTEN), highly frequent events in human cancer, confers ferroptosis resistance in cancer cells. This resistance requires sustained activation of mTORC1 and the mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR)C1-dependent induction of sterol regulatory element-binding protein 1 (SREBP1), a central transcription factor regulating lipid metabolism. In conclusion, this study provides a mechanism of resistance to ferroptosis in cancer cells, and the identification of a therapeutic strategy that targets this mechanism may lead to the development of new cancer therapies. Hypertension is the leading cause of heart failure, the most common type of heart disease. The treatment of hypertension is the cornerstone of the prevention of heart failure. The most common drugs for treating hypertension are the L-type Ca2+ channel blockers (LCCBs). Our study shows that LCCBs act on the STIM N terminus to cause STIM relocalization to junctions and subsequent ORAI activation in a Cav1.2-independent and store depletion-independent manner. LCCB-induced promotion of vascular remodeling requires STIM1, which is up-regulated in VSMCs from hypertensive rats. Our data indicate caution against the use of LCCBs in elderly patients or patients with advanced hypertension and/or onset of cardiovascular remodeling, where levels of STIM and ORAI are elevated. Our study unravels a mechanism of LCCBs action on Ca2+ signaling and demonstrates that LCCBs promote vascular remodeling through STIM-mediated activation of ORAI. This study provides a rationale for the use of LCCBs in the treatment of hypertension. (Show more)

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy for the conservation of biodiversity on federal land. We show that the NWFP has not been successful in reversing the decline of older-forest–associated bird populations. We also show that the creation of early-seral ecosystems on federal land may be a useful tool for the conservation of these species, but that this approach may be limited by the continued need for clearcutting on federal land.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. This problem can be addressed by the development of new antibacterial agents to keep pace with the evolutionary adaptation of pathogens. In this study, we present a rational design approach, in which acylide antibiotics were screened based on computational predictions of solubility, membrane permeability, and binding affinity toward the ribosome. To assess our design strategy, we tested all candidates for in vitro inhibitory activity and then evaluated them in vivo with several antibiotic-resistant strains to determine minimal inhibitory concentrations. The best compounds designed by us show activity, especially when combined with the membrane-weakening drug colistin, against Acinetobacter baumanii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Escherichia coli, which are the three most critical targets from the priority list of pathogens of the World Health Organization. This study provides a proof of concept for the rational design of new antibiotics. The design strategy can be extended to other classes of antibiotics and to other targets of interest. This work is expected to contribute to the development of new antibiotics to combat the growing threat of antibiotic resistance. (Show more)

We introduce a new network architecture that is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters. The architecture is based on a single set of operations, making it easier to implement, train, and apply in practice. We compare results of the proposed network architecture with popular existing architectures for several segmentation problems, showing that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data. The proposed architecture is expected to be useful for many image-processing problems. We hope that the code and data will be useful for the community.

We present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of continental hydroclimate and lake-level variability from Lake Malawi, East Africa. This record provides a unique perspective on the evolution of the tropical climate and the impact of this on the evolution of the Lake Malawi cichlid fish species flock. We observe dramatic shifts in effective moisture, resulting in large-scale changes in one of the world’s largest lakes and most diverse freshwater ecosystems. The record shows evidence for 24 lake level drops of more than 200 m during the Late Quaternary, including 15 lowstands when water levels were more than 400 m lower than modern. A dramatic shift is observed at the Mid-Pleistocene Transition (MPT), consistent with far-field climate forcing, which separates vastly different hydroclimate regimes before and after 800,000 years ago. The record provides a unique perspective on the impact of extreme hydroclimate variability on the evolution of the Lake Malawi cichlid fish species flock.

The use of electronic devices in the hours before bedtime is widespread, but the impact of these devices on sleep is unknown. Here we show that reading an electronic book on a light-emitting device for 1 h before bedtime results in a delayed circadian clock, reduced melatonin levels, and reduced sleepiness. These effects are likely to have important implications for performance, health, and safety.

The impact hypothesis for the Younger Dryas cooling has been debated for decades. One of the main arguments against the impact hypothesis is the lack of evidence for a bolide impact at the YDB. We show that the osmium isotopic composition of magnetic grains and microspherules from the YDB sites is consistent with a terrestrial origin, and the spherules from the YDB site in Pennsylvania are consistent with their source being in the Grenville Province of northeastern North America, which is 1.5 Ga old.

The role of CTLA-4 in the immune system is controversial, and its specific function in the development of autoimmunity is still to be determined. Here, we show that the deletion of CTLA-4 in adult mice results in a spectrum of autoimmunity, which is not fatal but can be exacerbated by the presence of Treg cells.

Beetles are arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the evolutionary history of beetles, including the impacts of plant feeding on beetle diversification, remain poorly understood. We used a combination of genomic and fossil data to trace the evolution of beetles, and found that the origin of beetles coincides with the origin of the plant kingdom, and that plant cell wall-degrading enzymes may have been key to the Mesozoic diversification of herbivorous beetles.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work has the potential to accelerate the development of new therapeutics to combat the COVID-19 pandemic. (Show more)

We show that the size of a population does not enhance the cumulative cultural evolution of technology. We also show that the size of a population does not enhance the cumulative cultural evolution of technology when the population is large.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia and the fifth leading cause of death in the United States. The strongest genetic risk factor for AD is the apolipoprotein E (APOE) genotype. APOE has three common isoforms in humans, E2, E3, and E4. The presence of two copies of the E4 allele increases risk by ∼12-fold whereas E2 allele is associated with an ∼twofold decreased risk for AD. These data put APOE central to AD pathophysiology, but it is not yet clear how APOE alleles modify AD risk. Here, we report a novel role for APOE in controlling the phagocytic capacity of astrocytes that is highly dependent on APOE isoform.

The inner core is the densest part of the Earth, and its formation is one of the most important problems in geophysics. However, the mechanism of its formation is still unknown. We show that the bcc phase of iron has a higher nucleation rate than does the hcp phase under inner core conditions. This mechanism reduces the required undercooling of iron nucleation, which provides a key factor in solving the inner core nucleation paradox.

Marijuana is the most commonly used illicit drug in the United States, and its use is increasing among adolescents. The effects of chronic marijuana use on the brain are not well understood. Here, we show that chronic marijuana use is associated with reduced brain reactivity to methylphenidate, a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine (DA) levels in the brain. This reduced reactivity is associated with increased stress reactivity and irritability, and increased addictive behaviors.

Language is a uniquely human ability, and the brain’s neural mechanisms for comprehending it are among the most complex and mysterious aspects of the human mind. Here, we use the most powerful artificial neural networks in the world to make novel predictions about the brain’s neural responses to language.

Deep learning (DL) has been a major advance in machine learning, but it has been criticized for its instability. We show that this instability is due to the fact that DL is a special case of a more general problem, which is well-posed in the sense that there exist algorithms that compute stable solutions. We introduce a new class of networks that we prove are stable, and we show that only a small number of layers are needed to achieve a given accuracy. Our results have implications for the design of DL algorithms and for the development of DL in scientific computing.

In the 1970s, a classic experiment was conducted to study the relationship between growth and understanding. The experiment’s design flaws were not noticed at the time, but are now widely discussed. This is a unique case study of researchers falling prey to just the cognitive bias they set out to study—undermining an experiment’s methodology while, ironically, still supporting its conclusion.

Leprosy is a disease that has been with us for thousands of years, and is still with us today. We have known for a long time that there are two distinct species of leprosy bacillus, but the reasons for this are not clear. We have now sequenced the genome of a third species, which is associated with a rare form of leprosy known as lepromatous leprosy.

The dynamics of entanglement and entropy in isolated quantum systems is a fundamental question of fundamental importance. We show that the entanglement dynamics in the space–time scaling limit can be understood in terms of quasiparticles, which are the elementary excitations of the system. This result is a direct consequence of integrability and is expected to be valid for a large class of quantum many-body systems.

COVID-19 is a highly contagious disease that has caused more than 5 million deaths worldwide. The only vaccine currently in clinical development is the one developed by COVI-VAC. We show that the vaccine is highly attenuated, and that it can protect hamsters from the disease.

Plague, caused by Yersinia pestis, is one of the most devastating diseases in human history. The Second Pandemic (14–19th centuries) led to high mortality and recurrent epidemics for hundreds of years. We developed a compartmental model for plague transmission by a human ectoparasite vector. Using Bayesian inference, we found that this model fits mortality curves from nine outbreaks in Europe better than models for rodent or pneumonic transmission. Our results support that human ectoparasites were primary vectors for plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death (1346–1353), ultimately challenging the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats. This study provides a better understanding of the history of plague and the role of human ectoparasites in the spread of the disease. It also provides a framework for studying the role of human ectoparasites in the spread of other vector-borne diseases.

The evolution of the brain is one of the most important topics in biology. However, the evolution of brain size as a proxy for cognitive ability is biased by the fact that brains of larger animals are bigger. This study shows that the evolution of brain size is not the only factor that determines the cognitive ability of animals. We show that the evolution of brain size is not the only factor that determines the cognitive ability of animals.

The role of TRAP1 in cancer has been the subject of intense investigation, but the results have been mixed. We have found that TRAP1 is required for the survival of cells that have acquired oncogenic mutations, and that TRAP1 is required for the invasiveness of cells that have acquired oncogenic mutations. These data suggest that TRAP1 may act as a tumor suppressor.

Actin depolymerizing factor (ADF)/cofilin is a protein that is involved in severing actin filaments. Severing is a key process in many cellular processes, including cell migration, cytokinesis, and cytokinetic arrest. However, the mechanism by which ADF/cofilin does so is not well understood. Here, we use single-molecule, single-filament, and filament network techniques to study the action of ADF/cofilin in different mechanical situations. We find that ADF/cofilin enhances severing by increasing the torque on the filaments. This mechanism is critical to boost ADF/cofilin’s ability to sever highly connected filament networks in cells. Our results provide a mechanism for how ADF/cofilin can sever actin filaments in a physiological context.

Fructose, a common sweetener, is often used in place of glucose in processed foods. This study shows that fructose relative to glucose results in greater brain activation in regions involved in attention and reward processing and may promote feeding behavior. These findings have implications for our understanding of the effects of sugar-sweetened beverages on appetite and food-seeking behavior, and may help explain why some people are more susceptible to the effects of sugar than others.

Madagascar is a unique island in terms of its biodiversity and its human population. The settlement history of Madagascar is still debated, and we provide a comprehensive view of the genetic diversity of the Malagasy population. We show that the Malagasy population is a mixture of African and Asian populations, with a recent origin. However, the distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the admixture was sex biased and happened heterogeneously across Madagascar, suggesting independent colonization of Madagascar from Africa and Asia rather than settlement by an already admixed population. In addition, a few centuries is sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. These results provide a better understanding of the human history of Madagascar and may help to explain the unique genetic diversity of the Malagasy population. They also provide a reference for the study of human genetic diversity in the Indian Ocean.

We show that people’s emotions are influenced by the emotions of others in a large social network. This work has implications for our understanding of the spread of emotions in society, and for the design of social networks that are more positive.

The presence of RNA modifications in coding regions of messenger RNAs (mRNAs) has been shown to impact protein synthesis. However, the impact of modifications in the coding regions of mRNAs on translation speed and fidelity has not been studied. Here, we show that the presence of a modification in the mRNA can impact the fidelity of translation. We find that the presence of a modification in the mRNA can impact the fidelity of translation.

This study shows that the feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including better health, more social engagement, and a healthier lifestyle. This finding has implications for the promotion of healthy aging and the development of interventions to improve the subjective experience of life as people age.

The evolution of aquatic life has led to the development of a number of adaptations that allow mammals to thrive in the water. These adaptations, however, have not led to a reduction in body size. Here, we show that the evolution of an aquatic lifestyle is driving three of the four extant aquatic mammal clades toward a size attractor at ∼500 kg. This size attractor is consistent with the energetic demands of the aquatic medium.

Rhinovirus is the most common cause of the common cold, and the ability of the virus to replicate more efficiently at the cool temperatures found in the nasal cavity than at core body temperature is a key factor in the pathogenesis of the common cold. This study demonstrates that the temperature-dependent growth phenotype of rhinovirus is due, in part, to a less efficient antiviral defense response of infected cells at cool temperature. These findings have implications for the development of rhinovirus vaccines and antiviral therapies.

Bacteria use a variety of sensing systems to respond to environmental signals. Here we show that the opportunistic pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa uses the mechanical activity of its type IV pili to detect contact with surfaces. This mechanism is important for the pathogen’s ability to attach to surfaces, which is a key step in the infection process. Our results demonstrate that type IV pili are not only used for twitching motility, but also as a sensor that regulates surface-induced gene expression and pathogenicity. This finding has implications for our understanding of the evolution of sensing systems in bacteria and the regulation of surface-induced gene expression in general.

The use of pesticides in agriculture has increased dramatically over the past decades, and the number of pesticides available to farmers is still increasing. This study provides a comprehensive analysis of the global pesticide situation, which is of great importance for the future of agriculture and the environment. We show that the use of pesticides in agriculture is not only a threat to human health but also to the health of the environment.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a profound impact on human health and the global economy. However, the role of animals in the transmission of SARS-CoV-2, the virus that causes COVID-19, is poorly understood. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in the blood of free-living white-tailed deer, and the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in the lymph nodes of captive and free-living deer. These findings have important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic, and highlight the need for a “One Health” approach to study the ecology, molecular evolution, and dissemination of SARS-CoV-2.

The proliferation of large dams in the developing world is a major concern for the environment, people, and the climate. This paper examines the history of the development of hydropower, the proliferation of large dams in the developing world, and the challenges of building sustainable hydropower. We also propose innovative solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices together with solar, wind, and other renewable sources.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia, and the lack of effective treatments has led to a worldwide public health crisis. Here, we identify the amyloid precursor protein (APP) neuron as a source of an early inflammatory response, which may precede the formation of amyloid plaques and tau tangles. This finding has implications for the development of novel AD therapeutics, as it suggests that targeting the accumulation of soluble and oligomeric amyloid species within neurons may be a promising strategy for the treatment of AD.

The domestic chicken is one of the most widespread domesticated species in the world. However, the earliest evidence for its economic exploitation is still missing. We present a new site from the Southern Levant, Maresha, where the exploitation of chickens was widespread and where the ratio of female to male bones is 2:1, a pattern that is characteristic for economic species. This evidence, together with a survey of the chicken bone-to-total-bone ratio from 234 sites in the Southern Levant, shows a sharp increase in the frequency of chicken during the Hellenistic period. We suggest that the gradual acclimatization of chickens in the Southern Levant and its gradual integration into the local economy, the latter fully accomplished in the Hellenistic period, was a crucial step in the adoption of this species in European husbandry some 100 y later.

We have developed a method that allows us to study the folding of proteins at the level of the individual residue. This method has been used to study the folding of maltose binding protein, a protein of 370 residues. The results show that the folding of maltose binding protein is a two-step process. The first step is a fast compaction of the protein into a polyglobular state. The second step is a slow formation of a native-like folding intermediate. The intermediate is an obligatory step on the folding pathway and is destabilized by mutations that slow the folding process.

We have discovered a previously unknown role for the bacterial RNA pyrophosphohydrolase RppH, which is inactivated by disulfide stress. In addition to its role in the degradation of 5′ capped RNAs, RppH is now shown to be a key player in the removal of 5′ noncapped RNAs, which are abundant in cells experiencing stress. This work provides insight into the mechanisms by which bacteria can adapt to stress, and it may have implications for the development of new antibacterial strategies.

Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with high mortality and poor clinical outcomes. The immune dysfunction that occurs during sepsis is associated with a number of adverse clinical outcomes, including secondary infections, organ failure, and late mortality. We hypothesized that increasing arginine availability would restore immune function and decrease immunosuppression during sepsis. We found that arginine administration was more efficient than citrulline in increasing arginine plasma levels and restoring T cell mitochondrial function and proliferation while reducing immunosuppression. Because there is no specific therapeutic strategy to restore immune function after sepsis, we believe that our study provides evidence for developing citrulline-based clinical studies in sepsis. This study also provides evidence for the use of citrulline as a potential therapeutic agent in sepsis.

We provide a global census of the biomass of all kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined, and that the biomass of animals is an order of magnitude higher than that of plants.

We introduce a new model of self-organized criticality (SOC) that is continuous in contrast to all known models of SOC. We show that our model is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model, the first and archetypical model of SOC. We discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim in this paper is to present an idealized tropical toy model, requiring further investigation.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal and electrical conductivity. It is a promising material for optoelectronic and quantum applications. However, its electronic and optical properties are sensitive to defects, and it is difficult to control its properties. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized, and its bandgap can be fully closed, without phonon instability. This work offers opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond via strain engineering for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications.

This study provides a structural basis for the antifungal activity of a class of nodule-specific peptides. It also provides a structural basis for the antifungal activity of a class of nodule-specific peptides. The male–female reproductive interface is a critical site of interaction between the sexes, and it is likely that the life history of sperm is intimately linked to the female reproductive tract. Here, we provide a comprehensive characterization of the life history of the Drosophila sperm proteome and show that the female reproductive tract makes substantial contributions to the sperm proteome. Our research provides a comprehensive characterization of the life history of the Drosophila sperm proteome and shows that the female reproductive tract makes substantial contributions to the sperm proteome. These findings expand our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. (Show more)

The protein von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a large, multidomain protein that binds to platelets, in part, by binding to glycoprotein Ibα (GPIbα) on the surface of platelets. We show that force application to VWF switches the receptor to a second state with faster on-rate, providing a mechanism for activating VWF binding to platelets. This mechanism is important for understanding the pathophysiology of von Willebrand disease, a common human bleeding disorder. The conversion of single molecule kon (s−1) to bulk phase kon (s−1M−1) and the kon and koff values extrapolated to zero force for the low-force pathways show remarkably good agreement with bulk-phase measurements. This suggests that the low-force pathways are in the same universality class as the high-force pathways. This is the first time that this has been observed for a protein.

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been the focus of intense study for the past decade. However, the role of viruses in human health has been more difficult to study, in part because of the lack of a comprehensive database for human-associated viruses. This study provides a comprehensive resource for human-associated viruses, which will enable future studies to investigate the role of viruses in human health.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is one of the most important processes in the climate system. However, the ACI is difficult to be well represented in current climate models. This is due to the lack of observational capability. We introduce a new technique, the dual-field-of-view high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL), to investigate the ACI. The HSRL can provide high-resolution and simultaneous observations of aerosols and clouds, especially water cloud microphysical properties. A case study over Beijing shows that the HSRL can provide significant contributions to the ACI investigations. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI. This technique will provide a new way to study the ACI. It will also provide a new way to study the climate system. Thus, the HSRL will be a significant contribution to the global climate change research.

The temperature of Earth’s surface has been a topic of interest for many years. The temperature of the surface of the Earth in the past can be inferred from the isotopic composition of marine sediments, but this method is subject to uncertainties. We here present a method for determining the temperature of the surface of the Earth in the past based on the thermostability of enzymes reconstructed from ancient DNA.

Ion channels are the main ion-conducting proteins in the cell membrane. They are also the main targets for drug development. Ion channels are open or closed, and the open probability is controlled by the channel’s gating. We found that the large-conductance calcium-activated potassium (BK) channel’s gating is closed state-dependent, and that its closing is also controlled by the channel’s open probability.

Malaria is one of the most devastating diseases in the world, with 1 million deaths occurring each year. Despite the development of antimalarial drugs, the disease remains a major public health problem. The malaria parasite uses a number of mechanisms to invade the red blood cell, the process of invasion, which is the start of the disease. Here, we show that the malaria parasite alters the physical properties of the red blood cell, which may facilitate invasion. This study provides a new perspective on the invasion process and may lead to the development of new antimalarial drugs. (Show more)

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal and electrical conductivity. It is a promising material for optoelectronic and quantum applications. However, its electronic and optical properties are sensitive to defects, and it is difficult to control its properties. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized, and its bandgap can be fully closed, without phonon instability. This opens up opportunities for tailoring its properties for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications.

In this study, we show that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our study provides insights into the role of humidity in host defense against influenza infection and the development of severe disease. These findings may help us to understand the impact of climate change on the severity of influenza outbreaks and the development of severe disease. This study also provides a better understanding of the role of humidity in the pathogenesis of influenza-associated pneumonia.

We show that the brain’s activity during the construction of a sentence is consistent with the idea that the brain first merges words into phrases and then phrases into clauses. This is the first time that such a merge operation has been observed in the human brain.

We have identified a mechanism of gene redundancy that is not only present in the Wnt pathway, but also in other signaling pathways. This mechanism may be important in the regulation of the expression of redundant genes in different tissues.
This study provides a detailed description of the brain circuit that may promote overeating and contribute to obesity.

The ability of plants to fix nitrogen from the atmosphere is a key process in the global nitrogen cycle and is fundamental to the functioning of the biosphere. However, the natural ability of many plants to fix nitrogen is limited, and the process is not effective in many agricultural settings. This work represents a key step toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This work is a significant step toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species.

We study the effects of a community-based monitoring program in the Peruvian Amazon that combined remote-sensed deforestation alerts with training and incentives for community members to patrol forests in response to those alerts. We find that the program reduced tree cover loss, but the estimated effects from the experiment are imprecise. Our findings suggest that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management.

We show that the web of a spider is an acoustic antenna that can detect the motion of air particles, which is the fundamental property of hearing. This allows the spider to detect the presence of an object, even if it is not in direct contact with the web.

We show that a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C.

COVID-19 is a global pandemic with no approved vaccine. We report the design, synthesis, and characterization of a SARS-CoV-2 RBD protein that is well-suited for large-scale production and elicits high-affinity antibodies. This protein can be used to generate a virus-like particle (VLP) vaccine, which can be produced at a high yield and is expected to be cost-effective. This protein can also be used to generate a subunit vaccine, which is expected to be cost-effective and easy to manufacture.

We show that the zebrafish ALK homologue, DrLtk, and human ALK are activated by the three zebrafish ALKALs. We also show that loss of the three ALKALs causes iridophore loss in zebrafish larvae and that loss of DrLtk causes iridophore development in the eye of the fruit fly Drosophila melanogaster. These results provide in vivo evidence of the involvement of ALK/LTK family receptors in neural crest development.

The emergence of plague from its Yersinia pseudotuberculosis progenitor is a key event in the history of the genus Yersinia, and the study of ancient genomes has provided a unique opportunity to explore this process. We present 17 Y. pestis genomes from the Late Neolithic to the Bronze Age, which provide a more complete picture of the evolution of plague during this period. We find that plague rapidly spread across Eurasia, and that the evolution of the pathogen was not uniform across the continent. These data provide a more complete picture of the evolution of plague and its relationship to its host, and may provide insights into the origins of plague in the human genome. (Less)

This work examines the role of the culturally endorsed form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—in men’s and women’s support for Donald Trump in the days (Studies 1 and 2) and months (Studies 3 through 6) following the 2016 American presidential election. In contrast to a populist explanation of support for Trump, HM predicted voting for and evaluations of Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. HM was associated with less trust in the government, more sexism, more racism, and more xenophobia but continued to predict unique variance in evaluations of Trump when controlling for each of these factors. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of HM legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies via candidate support.

The management of agricultural lands has been shown to be a major driver of the global C cycle. In the United States, the conversion of grassland to cropland has led to a loss of soil carbon, which is now the largest source of anthropogenic greenhouse gas emissions. We show that the management of agricultural lands can be used to mitigate this loss. We demonstrate that the management of annual cropping systems with cover crops, legumes, and manure can increase soil carbon storage, and that the management of grasslands with rotational grazing can increase soil carbon storage on a global scale. These results highlight the importance of agricultural management in the mitigation of climate change.

We provide a comprehensive assessment of the risk of spillover and spread of novel viruses to humans, using data from a virus discovery project and public records of virus detections around the world. We identify 887 wildlife viruses with the greatest potential to cause a spillover and spread to humans, and we provide a ranking of these viruses that can be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions. The SpillOver platform is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health. This work provides a resource for the scientific community and public health officials to better understand the risk of novel viruses to human health.

Nectar is a reward that plants offer to pollinators for reproduction. One of the main rewards that plants offer to pollinators for visitation is nectar. Nesocodon mauritianus (Campanulaceae) produces a blood-red nectar that has been proposed to serve as a visual attractant for pollinator visitation. Here, we show that the nectar’s red color is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid termed nesocodin.

We present a study of the genetic ancestry of a group of women who lived in Bavaria in the early 6th century AD. Our results indicate that the genetic ancestry of these women was very heterogeneous, and that some of it was not from western Europe. In addition, we show that some of the women had features that were associated with the wearing of artificial skulls, which were used to treat cranial deformities. Finally, we show that many alleles associated with recent positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes ∼36% fatality in infected patients. To understand how bat coronaviruses transmit to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of HKU4 and HKU5. We found that dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), the receptor for MERS-CoV, is also the receptor for HKU4, but not HKU5. Despite sharing a common receptor, MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes demonstrated functional differences. These results establish DPP4 as a functional receptor for HKU4 and host cellular proteases as a host range determinant for HKU4. They also suggest that bat coronaviruses threaten human health because of their spikes’ capability to adapt to human cells for cross-species transmission. These findings are important for understanding the evolution of bat coronaviruses and for developing countermeasures against MERS-CoV. (Show more)

We describe the use of a cloud-based metagenomic sequencing platform to investigate a large cohort of febrile patients in Cambodia. We show that mNGS can be used to rapidly identify a variety of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens. This study demonstrates the feasibility of mNGS for pathogen surveillance in resource-scarce settings, and the potential for mNGS to be used to rapidly deploy public health response.

The human genome is replicated in a process that is highly similar to the process used by bacteria to replicate their DNA. However, the human genome is much larger and, as a result, the process is much slower. One of the major differences is that the lagging strand of the human genome is replicated by a single DNA polymerase δ (pol δ) that is responsible for replicating the DNA in the absence of a template. We have developed unique kinetic assays to measure the processivity and stability of pol δ. Our results indicate that pol δ is not a processive enzyme and that it dissociates from PCNA, the sliding clamp, at a rate that is much faster than the rate at which it synthesizes DNA.

The origin of life is one of the most important and challenging problems in science. In this paper, we describe the first demonstration of the replication of genetic information in the absence of proteins.

We use computer vision methods to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We find that neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements. Neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements. Neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities.

COVID-19 is a new type of pneumonia, which has caused a large number of deaths. The pathogenesis of COVID-19 is not clear, and there is no specific treatment. In this study, we found that tocilizumab, which targets the IL-6 pathway, can improve the clinical symptoms of severe and critical COVID-19 patients, and the mortality rate is significantly reduced.

Copper homeostasis is a critical process in fungi, and the role of natural products in this process is not well understood. Here we report the discovery of a fungal natural product, xanthocillin, that binds copper and has antimicrobial properties. This discovery has implications for the role of natural products in the homeostasis of copper, and the role of fungi in the environment and in human health.

The presence of tridymite in a sedimentary rock from Gale crater, Mars, is the first evidence of a low-pressure, high-temperature (>870 °C) SiO2 polymorph on another planet. The tridymite is cogenetic with other crystalline minerals, and the amorphous material is a mixture of precipitated silica, diagenesis products, and/or fracture/vein fill. The amorphous material is a record of multiple aqueous events, and the diagenesis of the sediment is a record of the history of the martian surface.

The impact of late-spring frosts on the performance of plants and animals is a major concern for agriculture, forestry, and wildlife management. We show that the geographic distribution of late-spring frosts is changing, and that this change is likely to increase the risk of frost damage in some regions. Our findings can help decision-makers to adapt to the changing spring-frost risk and to minimize the economic and ecological impact of late frosts.

Th17 cells are a recently discovered subset of CD4+ T cells that play a central role in the pathogenesis of certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, the role of Th17 cells in the development of disease is not well understood. Here we show that Th17 cells can directly contribute to the development of colitis by transitioning to Th1-like cells and that they can support the development of classic Th1 cells. These results suggest that Th17 cells are potent mediators of inflammatory bowel disease.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a devastating disease with no cure. We have developed a method to rapidly produce motor neuron-like cells from living patients with ALS, which can be used to study the disease and identify potential therapies. This will help us to understand the disease and accelerate the development of new treatments.

This study provides a unique example of a pathogen using an arthropod protein to alter the gut microbiota of its vector. This study also provides a model for how pathogens can use the host immune system to influence the composition of the gut microbiota, which may influence the pathogen’s ability to colonize the vector. The evolution of the avian tail is one of the most important transitions in the evolution of birds. The study of the evolution of the avian tail is important for understanding the origin and development of the modern avian bauplan. This study provides new insights into the evolution of the avian tail, and the origin of the short-tailed bird group.

We show that the water vapor in the stratosphere is increasing in response to warming in the troposphere. This is a positive feedback in the climate system, and it is the first time that such a feedback has been identified in a climate model.

The color of an animal is a key feature that allows it to blend in with its environment. In this study, we show that the color of anurans (frogs and toads) has evolved multiple times, and that the mechanism is the same—the presence of a protein that binds biliverdin, the pigment that gives the animal its color. This protein, which we named biliverdin-binding serpins, is most similar to human antitrypsin, but with a remarkable functional diversification. Our results present molecular and functional evidence of recurrent evolution of chlorosis, describe a biliverdin-binding protein in vertebrates, and introduce a function for a member of the serpin superfamily, the largest and most ubiquitous group of protease inhibitors.

Hypoxia is a feature of many solid tumors, and hypoxia-inducible factor (HIF)-dependent mechanisms are important in the development of cancer stem cells. We show that HIF-dependent expression of ALKBH5, an m6A demethylase, increases the expression of NANOG, a gene that encodes a pluripotency factor, and that ALKBH5 overexpression increases the percentage of cancer stem cells. Thus, HIF-dependent ALKBH5 expression may be a mechanism by which hypoxia promotes the development of cancer stem cells.

The first pocket Bibles were made in the 13th century. The source of the parchment, often called “uterine vellum,” has been a long-standing controversy in codicology. Here, we report a simple and objective method to identify the animal origin of parchment. We found no evidence for the use of unexpected animals, but did identify the use of more than one mammal species in a single manuscript, consistent with the local availability of hides. These results suggest that ultrafine vellum does not necessarily derive from the use of abortive or newborn animals with ultrathin hides, but could equally well reflect a production process that allowed the skins of maturing animals of several species to be rendered into vellum of equal quality and fineness.

The end-Permian mass extinction was the most severe extinction event in the last 542 My. The age model for the extinction is critical for understanding the causes and mechanisms of the event, and for evaluating the plausibility of trigger and kill hypotheses.

Retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) is a transcription factor that is involved in various biological processes, including circadian rhythm, cancer, and metabolism. Here, we report that RORα is crucial for maintaining intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. We also show that RORα/HDAC3-mediated attenuation of NF-κB signaling controls the balance of inflammatory responses, and therapeutic strategies targeting this epigenetic regulation could be beneficial to the treatment of chronic inflammatory diseases, including inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). Our study provides insights into the role of RORα in intestinal homeostasis and inflammatory responses. (Show more)

We have determined the structure of the spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 in complex with the human receptor ACE2. We find that the receptor binding domain of the spike glycoprotein contains a single mutation that is associated with a more open conformation of the receptor binding domain. This may facilitate receptor binding and may be associated with the increased infectivity of the mutant viruses.

We consider repeated games with tail-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend only on what happens in the long run. We show that every repeated game with tail-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States. We estimate that, in the absence of the pandemic, life expectancy at birth would have been 78.6 y in 2020, and at age 65 y, 82.2 y. The Black and Latino populations are estimated to experience declines in life expectancy at birth of 2.10 and 3.05 y, respectively, both of which are several times the 0.68-y reduction for Whites. Latinos, who have consistently experienced lower mortality than Whites, would see their more than 3-y survival advantage reduced to less than 1 y.

The chemical properties of matter are the basis of all chemistry. The chemical hardness and electronegativity of an atom are two of the most important properties of an atom, and they are the second- and first-order chemical potentials, respectively. We show that these properties decrease with pressure, and we discover that pressure-induced s-d orbital transfer makes Ni, Pd, and Pt “pseudo–noble-gas” atoms with a closed d-shell configuration, and the elements preceding them (Fe and, especially, Co, Rh, and Ir) electron acceptors, while the elements right after them (Cu, Ag, Zn, and Cd) become highly electropositive. We show the explicative and predictive power of our electronegativity and chemical hardness scales.

We show that human ignitions and fire suppression have been the dominant driver of changes in fire activity over the last century, and that this is likely to continue in the future. However, our results suggest that climate change has been the primary driver of warming over the last century, and that climate–carbon cycle feedbacks may be the dominant mechanism for future warming. This suggests that climate change may be the primary driver of future warming, and that climate mitigation strategies may be more effective at reducing warming than strategies to reduce greenhouse gas emissions.

This study provides a unique example of a host-symbiont system that is able to regulate the activities of a symbiotic community through the strategic provision of a single glycan. This glycan is catabolized by the symbionts, which in turn use the products of catabolism to maintain the stability of the symbiosis. This glycan is also required for the periodic acidification of the symbiotic organ, which enhances the activity of the symbionts. This study provides a new perspective on the role of glycans in the regulation of the activities of symbionts in animal-microbe mutualisms. (Show more)

We introduce a method to identify latent patterns in text data. We use a combination of machine learning and word embedding to identify a set of vectors that can be interpreted as latent topics. We then use these vectors to represent documents as topic sequences. This method can be applied to any domain, and can be used to identify latent patterns in text data from many domains. We illustrate our method with a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System. Our results provide a detailed quantitative picture of reporting about lethal violence and its gendered nature. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model patterns in text data. This method can be used to identify latent patterns in text data from many domains.

The Black Death, which killed millions of people in the 14th century, is one of the most devastating events in human history. This epidemic is generally understood as the consequence of a single introduction of Yersinia pestis, after which the disease established itself in Europe over four centuries. We show that the climate fluctuations that preceded regional plague outbreaks were the result of repeated reintroductions of the bacterium into European harbors from Asian reservoirs, with a delay of 15 ± 1 y. Our results suggest that the Black Death was the consequence of multiple introductions of the disease, rather than a single event.

We provide evidence that a densovirus is the cause of the asteroid mass mortality event on the Pacific Coast of North America. This is the first report of a densovirus causing a mass mortality event in a marine invertebrate.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is a heterogeneous disease with a poor prognosis. We show here that a monoclonal antibody targeting the IL1RAP (IL1R3) receptor is effective in xenograft models of human AML. We demonstrate that the observed therapeutic effects are mediated by effector-cell–mediated killing and that natural killer cells are a critical human effector cell type. We also show that the antibody can block IL-1 signaling, which is important for the growth of AML cells. These results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. This study also provides a proof of principle for the use of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of other diseases. (Show more)

Madagascar is a unique island in terms of its biodiversity and its human population. It is the only place in the world where the language and culture of the native population are from Africa, while the rest of the island is populated by people from Southeast Asia. We show that the human population of Madagascar has a common Bantu and Austronesian ancestry, but that the settlement history is complex. We find that the settlement of Madagascar happened in several waves, and that the population growth happened faster in some areas than in others. This suggests that the population growth was not uniform across the island, and that the population was not already admixed when the first people arrived.

Bacteria have evolved small RNAs (sRNAs) to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The 164-nucleotide RNA was previously shown to encode a 28-amino acid protein (denoted AzuC). We discovered the membrane-associated AzuC protein interacts with GlpD, the aerobic glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase, and increases dehydrogenase activity. Overexpression of the RNA encoding AzuC results in a growth defect in glycerol and galactose medium. The defect in galactose medium was still observed for a stop codon mutant derivative, suggesting a second role for the RNA.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work has the potential to accelerate the development of new therapeutics to combat the COVID-19 pandemic. (Show more)

Crop experts are the eyes and ears of farmers, providing information on the status of crops that is critical for the management of agricultural production. However, the information provided by crop experts is often not used in agricultural decision-making. We show that this is due to the lack of quantitative tools to analyze the information provided by crop experts. We propose a method to convert the information provided by crop experts into a quantitative variable that can be used to monitor crop status and predict crop yields. We show that this method can provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official forecasts released midseason. This method can be used to monitor crop status and provide early warnings of crop anomalies. This will help farmers to make better decisions and mitigate the impact of crop anomalies. This will also help to improve the efficiency of agricultural production and reduce the impact of crop anomalies on the environment.

Language processing is a complex task that involves the integration of information over time. Here we propose a mechanism for memory that is based on the adaptive changes in the firing rates of neurons. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can be used to bind information over time. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

The response of soil respiration to experimental warming is a key indicator of the potential for climate change to alter the carbon cycle. However, despite decades of research, the overall response of soil respiration to anticipated climatic warming remains unclear. Here, we present the largest global dataset to date of soil respiration, moisture, and temperature measurements, totaling >3,800 observations representing 27 temperature manipulation studies, spanning nine biomes and over 2 decades of warming. Our analysis reveals no significant differences in the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration between control and warmed plots in all biomes, with the exception of deserts and boreal forests. Thus, our data provide limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in major biome types, contrary to the results from multiple single-site studies. Our analysis adds a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming.

The molecular evolution of the plastid genome is a powerful tool for understanding the evolution of the plant kingdom. The transition from autotrophy to a nonphotosynthetic parasitic lifestyle is a major evolutionary event in the history of plants, which has been linked to the loss of photosynthesis and the acquisition of a parasitic lifestyle. We show that the transition to a parasitic lifestyle is linked to a relaxation of selection pressure on the plastid genome, which is accompanied by a stepwise reduction in the functional complexity of the genome. Our findings provide insights into the molecular evolution of the plastid genome and the evolution of the plant kingdom. They also provide a framework for understanding the evolution of the genome of other organelles.

The impact of anthropogenic climate change on the probability of extreme droughts in South Africa has not been quantified at the scale of the region. We use a high-resolution large ensemble to estimate the contribution of anthropogenic climate change to the probability of occurrence of multiyear rainfall deficits in the past and future decades. We find that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of the 2015–2017 rainfall deficit by a factor of five to six. The probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 25% by the year 2100 under an intermediate-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 2-4.5) and to 80% under a high-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 5-8.5). These results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in South Africa to future anthropogenic emissions. This work is important for understanding the impact of climate change on water resources and for informing water management strategies. (Less)

The discovery of quasicrystals in nature and in the laboratory has been one of the most important developments in science in the last 50 y. This paper describes the discovery of the oldest known anthropogenic quasicrystal, which was formed in the aftermath of the first nuclear explosion.

Photosynthesis is the primary source of chemical energy on Earth. The capture of solar radiation and its conversion to chemical energy is mediated by the (bacterio)chlorophyll pigments. The formation of the isocyclic fifth ring, the key reaction in photosynthesis, has remained a mystery for more than 60 y. This paper provides a detailed analysis of the evolution of the enzymes that catalyze this reaction, and their role in the origin of photosynthesis.

Neuroinflammation is a major feature of many neurodegenerative diseases, and neuroinflammation is also known to be associated with autoimmune diseases. Neuroinflammation is associated with the activation of mitogen-activated protein kinase kinase kinase, ASK1, which is known to be involved in the regulation of cell survival and death. In this study, we found that ASK1 is involved in the regulation of neuroinflammation in the central nervous system. We also found that ASK1 is involved in the generation of a proinflammatory environment in microglia/macrophages, which subsequently activates astrocytes to exacerbate neuroinflammation. Our findings suggest that ASK1 is a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation. This study provides a better understanding of the role of ASK1 in neuroinflammation and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for neurodegenerative diseases and autoimmune diseases. California is currently in the midst of a record-setting drought. We show that the probability of drought has increased in the past two decades, and that this increase is attributable to human activities.

Autism is a complex disorder with a genetic basis, and the identification of the causal genes is a major challenge. We used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that mutations of five autism-risk genes with diversified molecular functions all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility indicated by impaired reversal-learning. These reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, specifically, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. This study provides a molecular mechanism for autism and may facilitate the development of new treatments. (Show more)
This work is the most comprehensive cross-national demonstration of negativity biases to date, but it also highlights the potential for more positive content.

The CRAC channel is a key regulator of Ca2+ signaling in the immune system, and is also involved in a variety of other cellular processes. Mutations in the CRAC channel pore-forming protein ORAI1 or the Ca2+ sensing protein STIM1 result in severe immune dysfunction and nonprogressive myopathy. Here, we identify gain-of-function mutations in the cytoplasmic domain of STIM1, which are associated with Stormorken syndrome, and in ORAI1, which is associated with a Stormorken-like syndrome of congenital miosis and tubular aggregate myopathy but without hematological abnormalities. These data expand our understanding of the phenotypic spectrum of dysregulated CRAC channel signaling, advance our knowledge of the molecular function of the CRAC channel, and suggest new therapies aiming at attenuating store-operated Ca2+ entry in the treatment of patients with Stormorken syndrome and related pathologic conditions.
