We have developed a model of spreading disease in the fly brain that can be used to study the mechanisms of neurodegenerative disease. This model can be used to study the mechanisms of spreading disease, and may be useful for studying other processes that involve the movement of material throughout the brain.

Bats are increasingly recognized as potential reservoirs of many zoonotic viruses. However, the factors that contribute to virus spillover from bats are not well understood. Here, we identified a protein, MTX, that is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of the bat, Myotis pilosus, and demonstrated that MTX has the potential to facilitate viral infection. MTX potently inhibits proinflammatory proteases to induce immune tolerance and maintain high stability. This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting MTX-LTA4H. These findings may help to elucidate the role of bats in the emergence of zoonotic viruses and provide a basis for the development of novel antiviral therapies. (Show more)

Cancer is a disease of uncontrolled cell growth, and one-carbon metabolism is a key metabolic pathway that supports cell growth. Here we identify a metabolic vulnerability of cancer cells, and a targetable metabolic deficiency of a subset of cancer cells.

We show that the proteins that form inclusions in the brain and spinal cord of patients with ALS are not merely a subset of the native interaction partners of these three proteins, which are themselves supersaturated. To explain the presence of coaggregating proteins in inclusions in the brain and spinal cord, we observe that they have an average supersaturation even greater than the average supersaturation of the native interaction partners in motor neurons, but not when scores are generated from an average of other human tissues. These results suggest that inclusion bodies in various forms of ALS result from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. This study provides a new perspective on the pathogenesis of ALS, and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. (Show more)

We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold cesium (Cs) atoms. The band structures of the 2D photonic crystals are predicted to produce unconventional atom–light interaction behaviors, including anisotropic emission, suppressed spontaneous decay, and photon-mediated atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal. An optical conveyor technique is presented for continuously loading atoms into the desired trapping positions with optimal coupling to the photonic crystal. The device configuration also enables application of optical tweezers for controlled placement of atoms. Devices can be fabricated reliably from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process, producing predicted optical properties in transmission and reflection measurements. These 2D photonic crystal devices can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter.

The study of the early evolution of the angiosperms is of great interest because it provides information about the origin of the most important group of flowering plants. The study of Montsechia, a plant from the Cretaceous, has allowed us to understand the origin of the Ceratophyllum clade, which is sister to the eudicots.

The evolution of viruses is a key topic in molecular biology, and it is often assumed that the evolution of DNA viruses is faster than that of RNA viruses. Here we show that this assumption is not always valid, and that the evolution of DNA viruses can be slower than that of bacteria. We also show that the evolution of B19V, a human pathogen, is slower than previously thought.

We provide a simple, quantitative estimate of the rate of sea level rise over the last 25 y, which is in agreement with the IPCC AR5. This estimate is based on a simple model of the relationship between the rate of sea level rise and the rate of climate change.

Pain is a major public health problem, and the number of Americans reporting pain is rising. However, the elderly report less pain than those in midlife. This is the mystery of American pain. We show that pain has been increasing with age for all adults, but that the rate of increase has been higher for those born after 1950. This pattern is not explained by changes in occupation or levels of obesity. If this trend continues, pain prevalence will continue to increase for all adults, with potentially serious implications for healthcare.

The study of enzyme mechanisms is a central goal of structural biology. In this work, we use NMR-assisted crystallography to provide a detailed, chemically characterized picture of the reaction pathway of the tryptophan synthase α-aminoacrylate intermediate. This study highlights the power of NMR-assisted crystallography to provide a detailed picture of the structure and dynamics of enzyme intermediates, and the role of these insights in understanding the mechanism of action of enzymes.

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe pneumonia caused by a coronavirus that emerged in 2012. There is no specific antiviral treatment, and the mortality rate is high. We show that remdesivir, an antiviral drug that is already in use for the treatment of Ebola, is effective in preventing and treating MERS. This is the first study to show that remdesivir is effective in a nonhuman primate model of MERS-CoV infection. This study supports the use of remdesivir in a clinical trial for MERS, and may also be considered for a wider range of coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV.

This study provides a unique example of a host-symbiont system in which the provision of a single glycan, chitin, is used to control the dynamics of a symbiotic community. This glycan is produced by the host, and its catabolism is required for the maintenance of the symbiont population and the production of bioluminescence at night. This glycan may be used by other hosts to control the activities of their symbionts.

This research has implications for the field of education, as well as for the fields of psychology, social work, and criminal justice. It suggests that the quality of teacher–student relationships can be improved, and that this can have a positive impact on students’ behavior and life outcomes. It also suggests that the quality of teacher–student relationships can be improved, and that this can have a positive impact on students’ behavior and life outcomes. The present study provides a comprehensive understanding of the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis. The results from this study will help us to better understand the molecular mechanisms of DNA repair and mutagenesis, which are important for the development of novel cancer therapies.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) infects humans from zoonotic sources and causes severe pulmonary disease. Virions require spike (S) glycoproteins for binding to cell receptors and for catalyzing virus–cell membrane fusion. We show that sequential proteolysis of MERS-CoV S proteins contributes to infection of human lung-derived cells, and that this process is important for virus tropism and virulence. These findings suggest that the first S cleavages may be significant determinants of MERS-CoV virulence.

This study provides evidence that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a cafeteria can increase sales of vegetarian meals by 40%. This is a large effect, and it is achieved with a simple change to the catering system. This study also provides evidence that the effect of increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available is concentrated among diners who are less likely to select vegetarian meals at the start of the study. This suggests that the effect is concentrated among the people who are most in need of the change. These findings have implications for the design of interventions to increase the proportion of plant-based meals available in cafeterias and other settings. They also have implications for the design of interventions to increase the proportion of plant-based meals available in cafeterias and other settings.

The cell surface proteome, the surfaceome, is the interface for engaging the extracellular space in normal and cancer cells. Here we apply quantitative proteomics of N-linked glycoproteins to reveal how a collection of some 700 surface proteins is dramatically remodeled in a cell line stably expressing any of six of the most prominent proliferative oncogenes, including the receptor tyrosine kinases, EGFR and HER2, and downstream signaling partners such as KRAS, BRAF, MEK, and AKT. We find that each oncogene has somewhat different surfaceomes, but the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes including up-regulation of nutrient transporters, down-regulation of adhesion molecules and tumor suppressing phosphatases, and alteration in immune modulators. These studies provide a broad systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. In response to the coronavirus pandemic, many scholars and policy makers are urging the United States to expand voting-by-mail programs to safeguard the electoral process. This paper provides a comprehensive design-based analysis of the effects of vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes. We find that vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and modestly increases overall average turnout rates. All three conclusions support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media.

The molecular basis for the severity and rapid spread of the COVID-19 disease caused by severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) is largely unknown. Here, we report the crystal structure of SARS-CoV-2 ORF8, which is a rapidly evolving accessory protein that has been proposed to interfere with immune responses. The structure reveals a unique dimerization interface that is specific to SARS-CoV-2, which may mediate unique immune suppression and evasion activities. These findings provide insight into the molecular basis of the COVID-19 disease and may lead to the development of new therapeutics. (Show more)

Hypoxia is a common condition in the human body, and it is also a major factor in the pathogenesis of many diseases. Here we show that hypoxia triggers cerebral edema in rats, and that this is mediated by the hypoxic release of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF), which acts on the CRF receptor type 1 (CRFR1) to trigger signaling of cAMP/PKA in cortical astrocytes, leading to activation of AQP4 and cerebral edema. This study provides a mechanism for the pathogenesis of cerebral edema in hypoxia, and may also be relevant to other conditions in which hypoxia triggers edema. This study also provides a rationale for the use of CRFR1 antagonists in the treatment of edema. (Show more)

We live in an age of big data. We have access to more data than ever before, and we have more powerful tools for analyzing these data. This article describes a new way of analyzing data that is appropriate for this era. The key idea is that we should not be satisfied with finding just one or two associations in a dataset. Instead, we should be satisfied only when we find associations that are very strong. This idea leads to new methods for analyzing data that are appropriate for the era of big data.

The development of vascular networks is a critical step in the regeneration of the liver, which is the most common indication for liver transplantation. However, the generation of vascular networks is a major challenge in the regeneration of the liver. Here, we demonstrate that ets variant 2 (ETV2) can induce the formation of vascular networks in the liver, which is a major step in the regeneration of the liver. Our study provides a promising approach for the regeneration of the liver. Furthermore, the creation of ETVECs provides further understanding of human EC development induced by ETV2. This study will contribute to the development of regenerative medicine. (Show more)

We have discovered a family of ligand proteins that are essential for the development of iridophores, a type of photoreceptor that is found in the eyes of many vertebrates. These proteins are encoded by genes that are not found in humans, mice, or rats.

In this study, we found that STING is required for β-cell function and insulin secretion. This study provides a better understanding of the role of STING in the regulation of glucose homeostasis and β-cell function.

Influenza A viruses are the main cause of seasonal epidemics and occasional pandemics. Their genome is segmented into eight fragments, which offers evolutionary advantages but complicates genomic packaging. The selective packaging of the viral genome is a fundamental process for the production of infectious virions. Here, we identified a direct intermolecular interaction between two viral genomic RNA segments of an avian influenza A virus. This interaction is required for optimal viral replication and nonspecifically decreases the amount of viral RNA in the viral particles, resulting in an eightfold increase in empty viral particles. Our results indicate that viral RNA segments can promote the selective packaging of the influenza A virus genome by forming a sequence-dependent supramolecular network of interactions. The lack of conservation of these interactions might limit genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses. (Show more)

The development of atherosclerosis is a complex process that involves a series of events, including the activation of proatherogenic phenotypes of vascular endothelial cells. In this study, we demonstrate that the activation of YAP/TAZ by disturbed flow is a critical event in the development of atheroprone phenotypes and the progression of atherosclerosis. Our results provide a mechanistic understanding of the role of YAP/TAZ in the development of atheroprone phenotypes and atherosclerotic lesions and suggest that inhibition of YAP/TAZ activation is a promising therapeutic strategy for the treatment of atherosclerosis. This study also provides a platform for the development of a new class of antiatherosclerotic drugs. (Show more)

Wildfire is a natural process that has been an integral part of the natural and human landscape for millennia. However, in the last 150 y, the economic and ecological costs of wildfire have risen dramatically. Climate change has likely played a role in the increase in wildfire activity, but the direct role of people in increasing wildfire activity has been largely overlooked. We show that humans have vastly expanded the spatial and seasonal “fire niche” in the United States, accounting for 84% of all wildfires and 44% of total area burned.

We use computer vision methods to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We find that neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements. Neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements. Neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities.

Natural repellents are a sustainable and eco-friendly method of pest control. However, the molecular targets of these repellents in arthropods remain to be further elucidated. Here, we report the identification of a scorpion TRP channel (sTRP1) that mediates the perception of natural repellents. This study provides a molecular target of natural repellents in arthropods, and may help in the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. It should also help in understanding the evolution of plant–arthropod interaction.

The recent outbreak of Zika virus (ZIKV) has been associated with neurological complications and fetal abnormalities, prompting global concern. Here we present a mathematical analysis of the within-host dynamics of plasma ZIKV burden in a nonhuman primate model, allowing for characterization of the growth and clearance of ZIKV within individual macaques. We estimate that the eclipse phase for ZIKV, the time between cell infection and viral production, is most likely short (∼4 h), the median within-host basic reproductive number R0 is 10.7, the rate of viral production is rapid (>25,000 virions d−1), and the lifetime of an infected cell while producing virus is ∼5 h. We also estimate that the minimum number of virions produced by an infected cell over its lifetime is ∼5,500.

Coral reefs are among the most diverse and valuable ecosystems on Earth. However, they are under threat from a variety of environmental stressors, including climate change. In this study, we show that the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis is a direct consequence of the altered nutrient cycling during heat stress. This process is driven by the host’s metabolic energy demand, which is increased by the heat stress, and the catabolic degradation of amino acids. These processes, in turn, promote the growth of algal symbionts and retention of photosynthates. Our results provide a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may ultimately help us to predict the stability of the coral–algal symbiosis in the face of future environmental change. The intestinal epithelium is the main barrier between the host and the external environment. In this study, we show that the loss of BMP signaling in the intestinal epithelium leads to the development of intestinal tumors, which in turn trigger a regenerative response in the microbiome and promote tumor growth. Our results identify a JNK-dependent feedback amplification loop between intestinal tumors and the microbiome. They also highlight the importance of controlling the activity level of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. These findings have implications for understanding the role of the microbiome in tumorigenesis and for developing new strategies to control tumor growth. (Show more)

Chemotherapy is a major component of the treatment of breast cancer, but the response to treatment is not universal. We show that targeting the ROR1 receptor, which is expressed in a subset of breast cancer cells, may enhance the response to chemotherapy.

The start of accelerated Antarctic ice sheet melting is often cited as a key trigger for the last, 60,000-y warming event, but the mechanism is uncertain. We show that a series of volcanic eruptions, coincident with the start of accelerated Antarctic ice sheet melting, plausibly led to stratospheric ozone depletion and changes in Southern Hemisphere climate that may have triggered the warming.

Freshwater fisheries are an essential source of food, recreation, and commerce for hundreds of millions of people worldwide. We provide a global map of riverine fisheries, which reveals that 90% of the world’s catch comes from river basins with above-average stress levels. Our analysis also shows that freshwater fisheries provide the equivalent of all dietary animal protein for 158 million people, many of whom are poor and undernourished. This highlights the importance of inland fisheries in providing locally sourced, low-cost protein, particularly in regions where alternative sources of nutrition and employment are scarce. However, the spatial coincidence of productive fisheries and low food security underscores the need for improved management of inland fisheries to protect biodiversity and ensure food security. Our data can be used to facilitate this process.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge, and aqueous Li-ion batteries draw large attention for this purpose. Due to the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes, the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials are significantly limited. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material (i.e., LixNb2/7Mo3/7O2) is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries.

We report on a form of regeneration in the nervous system that is independent of the canonical MAPK signaling pathway. This pathway is known to be required for regeneration in other systems, but we show that it is not required for regeneration in Caenorhabditis elegans. We also show that this form of regeneration is linked to activity-dependent ectopic axon outgrowth in the same neuron type. This study provides a unique platform for the discovery of genes involved in regeneration.

We have developed a method to precisely locate the locations of recombination events in a plant genome. This method can be used to study the distribution of recombination across the genome, and to investigate the relationship between recombination and gene structure. We find that recombination is more likely to occur in the promoter regions of genes than in the coding regions, and that the coding regions of genes are more likely to be converted than are the noncoding regions.

The resting state network (RSN) hypothesis has been proposed to explain the organization of the human brain in terms of functional connectivity. This hypothesis has been validated in healthy subjects, but the validity of the RSN organization in disease has not been established. We show that metabolic imaging can provide a direct measure of the organization of the brain in health and disease. We also show that metabolic imaging can provide a direct measure of the organization of the brain in health and disease.

We have discovered a new type of RNA modification in eukaryotes, which is found on a subset of mRNAs. This modification is found on the 5′ end of the mRNA, and is a 5′ nicotinamide-adenine dinucleotide (NAD+) group. We show that NAD-RNA is produced cotranscriptionally, and that it is found on pre-mRNAs, but not on mature mRNAs. This suggests that NAD-RNA could modulate the stability and translation of specific subsets of mRNAs.

Metabolic memory is the prolonged beneficial effects of intensive vs. conventional therapy on the progression of microvascular complications in people with diabetes. We show that DNA methylation differences at specific loci persist for several years during the follow-up of people with diabetes, and that these differences are associated with glycemia. These results support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory.

This study provides a mechanism for the role of FSIP1 in the sensitivity of triple-negative breast cancer cells to chemotherapy. This study also provides a potential target for the development of new therapies for triple-negative breast cancer.

Alcohol dependence is a chronic, relapsing, and progressive disease, which is characterized by a high mortality rate. The present study shows that some, but not all, alcohol-dependent subjects develop gut leakiness, which is associated with higher scores of depression, anxiety, and alcohol craving after 3 wk of abstinence. Moreover, subjects with increased gut permeability also had altered composition and activity of the gut microbiota. These results suggest the existence of a gut–brain axis in alcohol dependence, which implicates the gut microbiota as an actor in the gut barrier and in behavioral disorders. Thus, the gut microbiota seems to be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence.

The flavor of tomato fruit is a complex mixture of volatile chemicals, many of which are nitrogenous compounds. The biosynthesis of these compounds is not known, and the role of the genes involved in their production in the overall flavor of the fruit is unclear. Here we report the identification of a gene essential for the production of all the nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. This gene encodes a flavin-dependent monooxygenase that catalyzes the production of a series of nitrogenous volatiles, and the loss of function of this gene results in the accumulation of a single compound. This work provides a major step forward in understanding the biosynthesis of tomato flavor. (Show more)

We show that the impacts of global warming on the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning are not constant but depend on the temperature at which warming occurs. This result is driven by two processes: (i) the number of species required to maintain ecosystem functioning increases with temperature, and (ii) the contribution of complementarity to the net biodiversity effect increases at high and low temperatures. Our results highlight the importance of considering the combined effects of global warming and biodiversity loss on ecosystem functioning. This is critical for understanding the impacts of climate change on the functioning of natural systems and the services they provide to society.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a key hub for navigation, and its neurons are organized into distinct cell types that are thought to represent different aspects of space. However, the anatomical and functional organization of these cell types is not fully understood. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to record from a large number of neurons in the MEC of freely moving mice. We found that grid cells, which are thought to represent the internal representation of space, are organized separately from border, head-direction, and object-vector cells. These data suggest that grid cells may have a distinct organization from other cell types in the MEC. This study provides a detailed view of the organization of the MEC, which will be useful for understanding the function of this important brain area. (Show more)

Dodder is a root- and leafless plant that parasitizes a large number of autotrophic plants. The dodder plant does not synthesize its own food, but instead depends on its host plant for its nutrition. The dodder plant is able to synchronize its flowering with that of its host plant. This study shows that the flowering of the host plant is required for the flowering of the dodder plant. This study illustrates how regressive evolution, commonly found in parasites, may facilitate the physiological synchronization of parasite and host, here allowing the dodder plant to time reproduction exactly with that of its host plant. This may be an important mechanism for the success of the dodder plant.

The dopamine system of the brain is critical to movement and motivation. We show that the dopamine-containing neurons of the nigro system, which project to the striatum to form the classic nigrostriatal pathway, have a specialized system of connections that are not part of the classic pathway. These connections, which are likely to be critical to the function of the dopamine system, are not part of the classic nigrostriatal pathway.

We are all social creatures, and we all seek connection. We are also all busy, and we all have limited attention. We show that the speed at which we respond to others is a robust and honest signal of connection, and that this signal is used by others to gauge the quality of our social interactions.

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the primary pacemaker of the heart. The SAN is composed of specialized cardiomyocytes, which are responsible for the generation of the heart rate. The SAN is able to adjust its rate to meet the hemodynamic demand. This study reveals that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) is a multifunctional regulator of Ca2+ dynamics in SAN cells, which links SR Ca2+ store content with electrical events occurring in the plasma membrane, thereby contributing to automaticity of the SAN. These studies provide insights into the role of STIM1 in SAN physiology. (Show more)

Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plant growth and development, but its role in plant defense against insect herbivores has not been well understood. Here, we show that Si pretreatment of rice plants increases resistance against the rice leaffolder, a major insect pest of rice, and that this effect is mediated by the jasmonate (JA) signaling pathway. Our results suggest that Si and JA may interact to promote plant defense against insect herbivores. This study provides insights into the role of Si in plant defense and may lead to the development of Si-based pest management strategies for rice. (Show more)
This study provides a new view on the role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism and opens the door for further studies on the role of this cofactor in other cellular processes.

Language is a highly complex system that involves the integration of information over time. Here we propose a mechanism for memory in the brain that is based on the adaptive changes in the firing rates of neurons. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can be used to bind information over time. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

This work is a first step in the development of DNA nanostructures as a tool for the delivery of biomolecules to plants. We show that DNA nanostructures can be used to deliver biomolecules across the cell wall of plants, which is a major challenge in the delivery of biomolecules to plants. We also show that the size, shape, compactness, stiffness, and location of the siRNA attachment locus on the DNA nanostructure are important design parameters for the delivery and gene silencing efficiency. This work will help in the development of DNA nanostructures as a tool for the delivery of biomolecules to plants. This work will also help in the development of DNA nanostructures as a tool for the delivery of biomolecules to plants.

We show that the vast majority of the nutrients that fuel algal blooms in the world’s largest freshwater lake come from a small fraction of the smallest tributaries. This finding has important implications for the management of coastal ecosystems, which are often the most valuable and threatened areas of our lakes and rivers.

We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network in a thermodynamic environment that is biased toward rare combinations of chemical concentrations. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of environmental forcing. This behavior is reminiscent of the “fine-tuning problem” in cosmology, where the rare combination of initial conditions is required to produce the observed universe.

This study offers a unique insight into the mechanisms of action of a class of antibodies that are the cause of a devastating autoimmune encephalitis. The study provides a framework for understanding the effects of these antibodies on the brain, and how they can lead to paroxysmal EEG abnormalities. This knowledge can be used to develop new therapies for this devastating disease.

The history of carbon (C) perturbations throughout Earth’s history has provided key insights into how the Earth system responds to abrupt warming. Here, we present a study that provides a new perspective on the history of C perturbations during a global warming event that occurred during a glacial period. We show that the event was associated with a doubling of atmospheric CO2 and a biodiversity nadir. We also show that the event was associated with an injection of organic matter–derived C and with an increase in nutrient fluxes.

We show that the RSPO has had a positive impact on reducing deforestation in oil palm plantations, but that the benefits are limited by the size of the plantations and the age of the plantations at the time of certification. We also show that certification has had no impact on forest loss in peatlands or active fire detection.

The exocyst complex is a protein complex that is involved in the final steps of exocytosis, which is essential for the release of many proteins from the transiting vesicles. The exocyst complex is conserved across kingdoms, and its dysfunction is correlated with several significant diseases. We discovered a small molecule that binds to the EXO70 subunit of the exocyst complex, resulting in inhibition of exocytosis and endosomal recycling in both plant and human cells and enhancement of plant vacuolar trafficking. This study provides a valuable tool in studying exocytosis regulation and offers a potentially new target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. (Show more)

Sex determination is a fundamental process in biology, and the genetic basis of sex is a key component of sex differences in humans and other vertebrates. In this study, we investigate the effects of multiple interacting sex determination alleles on secondary sexual characteristics in a fish species with four possible sex classes. We find that the modularity of secondary sexual characteristics produced by multiple sex determination alleles can provide context for understanding the evolutionary causes and consequences of maintenance, gain, or loss of sex determination alleles in populations.

The retina is a unique organ in that it is challenged by two distinct classes of reactive oxygen species, one generated by photoreceptor cells and the other by the pigment epithelium. We show that the redox state of the retina is influenced by the intracellular levels of iron, which is known to be important in redox active energy and electron transfer.

Predators are the main drivers of ecosystems, and the evolution of their feeding strategies is a key process in the development of food webs. In this study, we show that the evolution of the feeding strategies of a group of predators, the siphonophores, is linked to the evolution of their morphology. This study contributes to a better understanding of the evolution of the feeding strategies of predators, and the role of morphological innovation in the development of food webs.

The human hand is one of the most iconic features of the human body. It is also one of the most complex, with a number of key joints that are the subject of intense debate about the evolution of the modern human hand. We present the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of a key feature of the modern human hand, the third metacarpal styloid process.

Cancer is a disease of uncontrolled cell growth, and one-carbon metabolism is a key metabolic pathway that supports cell growth. Here we identify a metabolic vulnerability of cancer cells, and show that this vulnerability can be targeted to block tumor growth.

This study shows that deforestation can have a negative impact on people’s diets, and that this impact is exacerbated by fragmentation of natural forests. This study has important implications for policy makers given that forests are largely overlooked in strategies to improve nutrition, but offer potential “win–wins” in terms of meeting nutrition goals as well as conservation and environmental goals.

Modern farm machinery has greatly increased the capacity of agricultural production, but the increase in vehicle weight has led to compaction of soil in deeper layers, which can have negative effects on soil ecological functioning. We show that the total weight of modern farm machinery is now comparable to that of the largest animals that walked Earth, the sauropods. We hypothesize that the roaming of sauropods on land would have had similar adverse effects on land productivity as modern farm vehicles, suggesting that ecological strategies for reducing subsoil compaction, including fixed foraging trails, must have guided these prehistoric giants.
